block.p: DEAR DIARY:
An insurance lawyer in Newark was telling me how he tried to emphasize the value of education to his teenage daughter.
DEAR DIARY:
An insurance lawyer in Newark was telling me how he tried to emphasize the value of education to his teenage daughter.
He told her that he had a B.A., an L.L.B., a J.D., a C.L.U., and a C.F.A.
''Dad,'' she answered, ''it doesn't mean a thing if you don't have a BMW.''
JERRY STEIN
MEMORIAL DAY
Atop the pole Old Glory flaps,
The trumpeter intoning taps
For those who gave their lives so you
Are free today to barbecue.
BOB McKENTY

When my oldest grandaughter, Natalie, was 4 years old, I took her home to my house without her parents for the first time. When I pressed the garage door opener and drove in, she said in amazement, ''The car goes in the garage?''
Recently, I picked-up my youngest granddaughter, Andrea, now 4, who lives in an older home with a detached garage. As I drove into the garage, she exclaimed, ''The house goes into the garage?''
This lead me to write:
GARAGES
Garages were designed to park the cars in which we ride.
Detached at first, they then were joined to where we all reside.
Soon they became the place where other things could hide.
And because there is no room, the cars are left outside!
ALICE GOULD
In recognition of Mother's Day recently, my son's first-grade class was asked to bring in an item that represented or reminded them of their Mom.

After careful consideration, my 7-year-old grabbed one of my aprons and headed off to school. When he came home I asked how show and tell went. He proceeded to tell me of the various Mommy mementos that were shared, including his own, which he said he proudly modeled.
When I asked if anyone laughed, he replied, ''Not as much as when I told them it was your uniform.''
DEIRDRE FLANAGAN WARD
And speaking of Mother's Day . . .
Scene: Friendly's Restaurant in Hackettstown on Mother's Day morning. One elderly woman, accompanied by a daughter, meets another elderly woman entering with her husband and introduces the daughter.
Daughter: ''Are you a friend from church?''
Second lady: ''Oh no, from the gym. We often pump iron together.''
How times change.
FLORENCE E. BRYAN
While shopping one night at a supermarket in Monroe Township, I overheard a young woman telling a friend:

''Personally, I think there should ber a supermarket where no one over 60 is admitted. I would be willing to pay more so I didn't have to contend with people who don't work, have no conception of time or why they're even there.''

I turned to her and said in a retaliatory tone: ''I suggest that you shop in the evening because seniors are fearful of going out at night. After all, there's the possibility of being mugged or shot by people under 60.''
HARRIET LEBOWITZ
MINIMUM WAGE
The minimum wage dictates minimum pay
Unless you're a juror at five bucks a day.
BOB McKENTY
